description: From Middle English margyn, from Latin marginem (possibly via Old French margin), accusative of margō (“edge, brink, border, margin”). Doublet of marge and margo.

entries.meaning: (typography) The edge of the paper, typically left blank when printing but sometimes used for annotations etc.
The edge or border of any flat surface.
(figuratively) The edge defining inclusion in or exclusion from a set or group.
examples: As far as space is concerned, Mary Lamb finds herself at the farthest margin of society - among tramps - when the novel begins.

entries.meaning: A difference or ratio between results, characteristics, scores.
A permissible difference; allowing some freedom to move within limits.
(finance) The yield or profit; the selling price minus the cost of production.
(finance) Collateral security deposited with a broker, to compensate the broker in the event of loss in the speculative buying and selling of stocks, commodities, etc.

examples: This model merely nips at the margins.

verbs.description: margin (third-person singular simple present margins, present participle margining, simple past and past participle margined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To enter (notes etc.) into the margin.
(transitive, finance) To trade (securities etc.) on margin (collateral).
